For all <math display="inline">a, b, c, d \in \mathbb{Z}, n \in \mathbb{N}^{\ge 1}</math> if <math display="inline">a \equiv c \;(\bmod\; n)</math> and <math display="inline">b \equiv d \;(\bmod\; n)</math>, then the following properties hold:

* <math display="inline">a  +  b  \equiv c  +  d \;(\bmod\; n)</math>
* <math display="inline">a  -  b  \equiv c  -  d \;(\bmod\; n)</math>
* <math display="inline">a  \cdot  b  \equiv c  \cdot  d \;(\bmod\; n)</math>

== Proof ==
* For the first, by expanding the definition of congruence, one must show <math display="block">n \mid \left( a  +  b \right)  -  \left( c  + d \right)</math>
** Notice that <math display="inline">\left( a  +  b \right)  -  \left( c  + d \right) = a  -  c  + b  -  d</math> and that <math display="inline">n \mid a - c</math> and <math display="inline">n \mid b - d</math> and so we get that <math display="inline">n \mid a - c  +  b  -  d</math>
** Thus we can conclude that <math display="block">a + b \equiv c + d \;(\bmod\; n)</math>
----
* The next one follows in a similar fashion this time using the fact that if <math display="inline">x \mid y</math> then <math display="inline">x \mid  - y</math> therefore we have <math display="inline">n \mid d  - b</math> then taking the sum of this equation and <math display="inline">a  -  c</math> we obtain <math display="inline">n \mid a  -  c  +  b  -  d = \left( a  -  c \right)  -  \left( d  -  b \right)</math>, so <math display="block">a  -  b \equiv c  - d \;(\bmod\; n)</math>
----
* The final comes from some algebra, first we notice that we want to prove that :<math display="block">n \mid ab  -  cd</math>
** That can partly be generated by <math display="block">\left( a  - b \right) \cdot \left( c  - d \right)= ac  -  ad  -  cb   +  cd</math> and so we have that <math display="block">ab  -  cd = \left( a  - b \right) \cdot \left( c  - d \right) +  ab   + cd  -  2cd</math>but then we can see that <math display="block">ad  +  cb  -  2cd = ad  -  cd  +  cb  -  cd = d \left( a  -  c \right)  +  c \left( b  - d \right)</math>
*** And since <math display="inline">n \mid a - c</math> and <math display="inline">n \mid b - d</math>, then <math display="inline">n \mid  d \left( a  -  c \right)  +  c \left( b  - d \right)</math>, which is <math display="inline">ab  \equiv cd \;(\bmod\; n)</math>
